competitors.name: ADP (Automatic Data Processing)
competitors.notes: Market leader with approximately 10% market share, dominant in payroll processing across all business sizes

competitors.name: Paychex
competitors.notes: Major payroll services provider with approximately 9% market share, strong in SMB market

competitors.name: Ceridian
competitors.notes: Payroll and HR services company, operating traditional service bureau model

competitors.name: Ultimate Software
competitors.notes: HR and payroll software provider, beginning transition to cloud-based solutions

competitors.name: Kronos
competitors.notes: Workforce management and time/attendance solutions provider

competitors.name: PeopleSoft/Oracle
competitors.notes: Enterprise HCM platform being acquired by Oracle in 2005

competitors.name: Sage Payroll
competitors.notes: Payroll software for small to medium businesses

context: In 2005, Paycom was a small, regional online payroll provider founded in 1998 by Chad Richison in Oklahoma City. The company was in its early growth phase, seven years after Richison sold his house and used his 401(k) to fund the startup. Paycom differentiated itself as one of the first fully online payroll providers with a single-database architecture. The market was dominated by ADP and Paychex who together held nearly 20% market share and served 1.8 million clients through traditional service bureau and bolt-on acquisition models. Paycom was building toward its 2007 investment from Welsh Carson Anderson and Stowe.
